question: What is the main objective of scheduling?
Which of the following is a primary objective of scheduling?
What does the term 'CPU Burst' refer to?
options: When a process is performing I/O operations
When a process is actively using the CPU for calculations
When the CPU is waiting for input

question: What is an example of I/O Burst in a process?
options: Waiting for input from the user
Using the CPU for intensive tasks

question: What is Preemptive Scheduling?
options: When processes run until they finish
When a higher-priority task interrupts a running process
When no processes are allowed to run concurrently

question: Which of the following is an example of Preemptive Scheduling?
Which scheduling algorithm uses fixed time slots for each process?
What happens in Non-Preemptive Scheduling?
options: The CPU can switch between processes at any time
The CPU executes processes until completion without interruption
A process can be interrupted by another of higher priority
Processes are always executed based on their arrival order

question: Which of the following is an example of Non-Preemptive Scheduling?
Which of the following is a common Non-Preemptive Scheduling algorithm?
What does the 'Throughput' criterion measure in scheduling?
options: The percentage of time the CPU is busy
The number of processes completed per unit time
The time a process spends in the queue
The time it takes for a process to complete

question: Which of the following scheduling criteria focuses on the total time taken for a process to complete?
What does the 'Waiting Time' criterion measure?
options: The total time spent by a process from arrival to completion
The time a process spends in the queue waiting for CPU access
The time it takes for a process to start execution
The amount of time the CPU spends idle

question: What is the main goal of Round Robin scheduling?
options: To give each process a fixed time slot to execute
To give the highest priority job the CPU first

question: In which scenario is Preemptive Scheduling most useful?
options: When a process is allowed to finish without interruption
When higher-priority tasks must be processed immediately
When processes should run based on arrival time
When all tasks have equal priority

question: What is an example of a process with a CPU burst followed by an I/O burst?
options: A student solving a math problem
A user typing on a keyboard
A process waiting for a disk read

question: Which of the following algorithms is a type of Preemptive Scheduling?

What does the 'Response Time' criterion focus on?
options: The total time for a process to complete
The time it takes for a process to start execution after a request
The percentage of time the CPU is busy
The time a process spends in the queue

question: What type of task does the CPU perform during a CPU burst?
options: Reading or writing data to disk

question: Which of the following best describes a Shortest Job Next (SJN) scheduling algorithm?
options: The CPU executes the process with the longest remaining time
The CPU executes the process with the shortest execution time
The process that arrives first gets executed first
The CPU executes processes based on priority

question: In which scenario would a Non-Preemptive Scheduling algorithm be most suitable?
options: When tasks must not be interrupted once they begin
When there is high overhead from context switching
When fairness between processes is crucial

question: What is the major disadvantage of Non-Preemptive Scheduling?
options: Increased overhead from frequent context switching
Processes may suffer from long waiting times

question: Which of the following is a disadvantage of Preemptive Scheduling?
options: Lack of flexibility in handling process priorities
More overhead due to frequent context switching

question: Which scheduling algorithm focuses on completing the process with the shortest remaining time?
What does the term 'Turnaround Time' refer to in scheduling?
options: The time a process spends waiting in the queue
The total time taken for a process to complete from arrival to completion
The time from when a request is made until it starts execution
The time spent by the CPU executing a process

question: Which of the following is an advantage of Preemptive Scheduling?
options: Simpler to implement and more predictable
Higher CPU utilization due to less context switching

question: Which scheduling algorithm gives the highest priority to the process with the shortest remaining time?

options: When tasks arrive in a specific order

It does not prioritize important tasks

It ensures fairness but with lower throughput

options: The time it takes for a process to complete
The total time spent by a process waiting in the queue
The time the CPU is idle
The time a process spends performing I/O operations

question: In Preemptive Scheduling, what can cause a process to be interrupted?
options: When a process has completed execution
When a process is waiting for I/O

question: Which scheduling algorithm assigns processes based on their arrival time?

options: When tasks have similar resource requirements

When all tasks are short in duration

options: All processes being executed in order
Equally distributing CPU time among all processes

options: It can result in longer waiting times

It leads to high CPU utilization
